topic1.message: I've seen elections in Delhi where the vote count was manipulated; history repeats when we ignore small signs.
The sudden shift in turnout after a scandal—it's a warning that democratic institutions can crumble if we don't guard them.

topic2.message: Truth is often inconvenient, like the real cost of colonialism. Why do you think people ignore it?
Because narratives shape perception; data can be abstract, while stories resonate emotionally.
Exactly. Literature reveals more about us than statistics ever will.

metadata.demographics: Indian Christian man, born in Delhi, 36 years old. Son of a bureaucrat, educated in philosophy at Oxford, now teaches political theory.
metadata.beliefs: Support the view that democracy is fragile and must be protected, according to him, history repeats when ignored, believes truth is often inconvenient, believes literature reveals more about people than data, believes personal freedom is sacred.
